The Contrarian · by Food Game Media
Why Your Restaurant Should Start With Disaster
23 February 2026
Opinion

Most operators believe flawless execution builds customer love. They polish every detail, rehearse every service, eliminate every possible failure point. Yet Italy's Winter Olympics tells a different story — one where disasters become the foundation for extraordinary connection.

The Games began terribly. Gaffe-ridden opening ceremony commentary that embarrassed the national broadcaster. Protesters clashing with riot police. Suspected sabotage attacks on railway networks by anarchists. The atmosphere in Rome was "subdued" while venues struggled with the most geographically scattered Winter Olympics ever, spread across 8,500 square miles with no central hub for celebration.

By every hospitality metric, this should have been a catastrophe. Instead, it became Italy's most successful Winter Olympics in history, with over 1.27 million spectators filling venues to 85% capacity and television audiences reaching 4.9 million viewers.

The secret lies in understanding what actually creates emotional investment. Perfect execution creates admiration, but struggle creates love. When guests watch you overcome adversity in real time, they don't just consume your service — they become collaborators in your success.

Think about your own dining experiences. The meals you remember aren't the flawlessly choreographed ones where nothing went wrong. They're the nights when the power went out and the chef cooked by candlelight, when the wine ran short and the sommelier opened their personal bottle, when rain flooded the terrace and everyone squeezed inside laughing. Disaster strips away the performance and reveals humanity.

Italy's Olympic organizers understood this intuitively. Chief executive Andrea Varnier didn't hide from the challenges, telling reporters "we know that this is not a walk in the park" and admitting they were "pioneers" facing unprecedented logistical complexity. This vulnerability created space for audiences to root for success rather than simply expect it.

The hospitality equivalent is the difference between a restaurant that runs like clockwork and one where you can sense the genuine effort. Guests can smell the desperation behind over-polished service, the emptiness of systems that never bend. But show them a team that's clearly pushing themselves for something meaningful, and they'll forgive almost anything.

Consider how Italian viewers embraced even curling — traditionally dismissed as boring — with 3.3 million people tuning in to watch Italy defeat Great Britain in mixed doubles. Why? Because they were watching their team strain for every point, not consuming pre-packaged entertainment. Investment transforms experience.

This explains why chain restaurants with perfect systems often feel soulless while struggling independents inspire fierce loyalty. The chain has eliminated all possibility of genuine surprise, both positive and negative. The independent makes you complicit in their survival. Every night feels provisional, alive with possibility.

The mistake most operators make is believing competence builds confidence. Actually, visible competence under pressure builds confidence. A bartender who makes perfect cocktails when the bar is empty proves nothing. A bartender who maintains quality while slammed on Friday night with two staff members sick and the POS system crashing — that's someone worth following.

Rome journalist Costanza Barone captured the essence perfectly when she described the Olympic viewing experience as "absolutely joyful" despite the chaos, praising how "young faces who seem very loyal to each other and even if they lose, they don't get cross." She wasn't celebrating perfection. She was celebrating grace under pressure.

Your restaurant doesn't need flawless nights. It needs authentic ones. Nights where something goes sideways and your team reveals who they really are. Where the kitchen runs behind and instead of panic, you see creativity. Where a supplier fails and staff improvise solutions that surprise even themselves.

This requires a fundamental shift in how you prepare for service. Instead of trying to eliminate all variables, prepare your team to handle variables brilliantly. Train them not just in procedures but in principles. Give them permission to break rules when breaking them serves guests better.

The scattered geography that should have doomed Italy's Olympics actually became its strength. With no single hub, each venue developed its own character, its own story of overcoming local challenges. Similarly, the nights your restaurant feels most alive are often the ones where standard operating procedures collapse and something more interesting emerges.

Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni celebrated medals on social media and cheered from the crowds, but she didn't create the magic. The magic came from watching ordinary people do extraordinary things under extraordinary pressure. From seeing what happens when preparation meets chaos and somehow produces gold.

Your next service disaster isn't a failure waiting to happen. It's an opportunity for your guests to fall in love with something real.

— JB

Source
The Guardian · https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2026/feb/22/how-italians-fell-in-love-with-their-winter-olympics-after-gaffes-turned-into-gold
